headline: A Second Opinion on Birth Control
snippet: To the Editor:    I am puzzled by all the noise in the media lately about eliminating menstruation through birth control pills (''New Pill Fuels Debate Over Benefits of Fewer Periods,'' Oct. 14).    The injectable contraceptive Depo-Provera, taken...

headline: National Briefing | Science And Health: Birth Control Pills With A 12-Week Regimen
snippet: A new birth control pill, to be taken 84 days in a row, instead of the usual 21, has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The advantage of the new pill is that users menstruate only about once every three months instead of once a month....

headline: Birth Control in Russia
snippet: For 50 years, Russian women relied on state-financed abortions as their main form of birth control. With pills, condoms and other contraceptives often in short supply, most women in Russia expected to face at least one and sometimes more than a dozen...

headline: Resisting Birth Control, the Philippines Grows Crowded
snippet: The more the merrier,'' said the cardinal, Jaime Sin, when asked a few years back about the country's population explosion, and his wish was granted.    The population in this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country has doubled in the last...

headline: 'Emergency' Birth Control: Access Issues
snippet: Five years after the Food and Drug Administration first approved a specially packaged formulation of birth control pills as a backup contraceptive method, experts estimate that 4 or 5 percent of women ages 18 to 44 have used the emergency...

headline: Emergency Birth Control
snippet: To the Editor:    The Personal Health column ''Fact of Life: Condoms Can Keep Disease at Bay'' on Jan. 21 suggests what to do if a condom breaks.
